occurrences.line_text: To reskue her from their rude violence,
Vouchsafe to reskue her against a Knight,
Ran after fast, to reskue the distressed mayde.
Had not a wondrous chaunce his reskue wrought,
To reskue him, and his weake part abet,
Which durst her dreaded reskue enterprize,
To reskue her, but when he saw the feend,
Mote them descry, nor reskue from their pray,
At last resolu'd to worke his finall smart,
Resolu'd to put away that loathly blame,
At last resolu'd likewise to proue the rest,
That she resolu'd, vnweeting to her Sire,
Malbecco seeing them resolu'd in deed
Resolu'd to build his balefull mansion,
Therewith resolu'd to proue her vtmost might,
That both resolu'd the last extremities to proue.
Resolu'd to end it one or other way;
I me resolu'd the vtmost end to proue,
Resolu'd with him to wend, gainst all her friends consent.
Resolu'd him to assault with manhood stout,
There she resolu'd her selfe in single fight
And then againe resolu'd to hunt him out
But she resolu'd no remedy to fynde,
Wayting, how Fortune would resolue that daungerous dout.
For I resolue this siege not to giue ouer,
I shal resolue, or backe to turne againe,
Resolued to pursue his former quest;
Resolued in one t'assemble all his force,
At last resoluing forward still to fare,
She vp arose, resoluing him to find
At last resoluing, like a pilgrim pore,
Therefore resoluing to reuenge his blood,
They both resoluing now to leaue the place,
Therefore resoluing, what it was, to know,
Therefore resoluing to returne in hast
His resolution was both first and last,
Resolv'd in minde all suddenly to win,
Far from resort of people, that did pas
Resort, to heare of straunge aduentures to be told.
And honour in their festiuall resort;
Ne suffreth he resort of liuing wight
That did resort of sinfull people shonne;
And euery one gan homeward to resort.
For neuer there the like resort they knew.
To which there did resort from euery side
There let her wonne farre from resort of men,
Therefore she vsed often to resort,
Vnto the which all louers doe resort,
Her selfe to pleasaunce, vsed to resort
Thither resorts, and laying his sad darts
These piteous plaints and dolours did resound;
Aboue the Moone, that fame may it resound
Through all the seas so ruefully resound,
That euer shrilling trumpet did resound;
Where wont the shepheards oft their pypes resound,
That all the fields resounded with the ruefull cry.
To Marinell, whose name the Heralds loud resounded.
Don Braggadochios name resounded thrise:
They made the further shore resounden wide:
That through the sea the resounding plaints did fly:
With that the rolling sea resounding soft,
That all the woodes and forestes did resownd;
And meet respect of honour put to flight:
Without respect of richesse or reward.
Gratious respect, thy wife shall backe be sent,
Without respect of person or of port,
And tortious powre, without respect or measure.
That to the Moone it mote be like in each respect.
But he it well did ward with wise respect,
With all due thankes, and dutifull respect,
And had he not that Dame respected more,
And trample th'earth, the whiles they may respire;
Ah Loue, lay downe thy bow, the whiles I may respire.
He cast to suffer him no more respire,
Whom when as he perceiued to respire,
Nothing but death can doe me to respire.
And he that breathlesse seemes, shal corage bold respire.
From their long vassalage gin to respire,
Where let them wend at will, whilest here I doe respire.
Ne once did yield it respit day nor night,
With royall arras and resplendent gold.
To th'instruments diuine respondence meet:
Yet nould she hearke, ne let him once respyre,
That from their noyance he no where can rest,
But wanting rest will also want of might?
Then with the Sunne take Sir, your timely rest,
Rest is their feast, and all things at their will;
Where cause is none, but to your rest depart.
He could not rest, but did his stout heart eat,
Yet she her weary limbes would neuer rest,
That a large share it hewd out of the rest,
Henceforth in safe assuraunce may ye rest,
From the fierce heat, and rest their weary limbs a tide.
That in their cotage small, that night she rest her may.
In stead of rest, she does lament, and weepe
Of which the first, that all the rest did guyde,
Emongst the rest rode that false Lady faire,
Which doen, the Chamberlain Slowth did to rest them call.
Returne from whence ye came, and rest a while
Can neuer rest, vntill it forth haue brought
Whereas that Pagan proud him selfe did rest,
To rest him selfe, foreby a fountaine side,
Sat downe to rest in middest of the race:
To rest them selues, and weary powres repaire,
And neuer vow to rest, till her I find,
Certes (said he) hence shall I neuer rest,
He there does now enioy eternall rest
But here lie downe, and to thy rest betake,
He chose an halter from among the rest,
Thy selfe to see, and tyred limbs to rest,
Iread you rest, and to your bowres recoyle.
Now when their wearie limbes with kindly rest,
The rest was all in yellow robes arayed still.
As Guardian and Steward of the rest:
There she awhile him stayes, him selfe to rest,
That to the rest more able he might bee:
Brings them to ioyous rest and endlesse blis.
And after litle rest, gan him desire,
And found no place his deadly point to rest.
Whiles from their iournall labours they did rest,
One that would wiser seeme, then all the rest,
Another said, that in his eyes did rest
Let vs deuize of ease and euerlasting rest.
Of ease or rest I may not yet deuize;
Toung hates to tell the rest, that eye to see abhord.
And in the rest his readie speare did sticke;
Loe I for pledges leaue. So giue me leaue to rest.
To let a wearie wretch from her dew rest,
To hinder soule from her desired rest,
To good and bad, the common Inne of rest;
Which who so wants, wants so much of his rest;
Who all this while were at their wanton rest,
To rest themselues, and grace to reconcile.
Ne euer shall I rest in house nor hold,
They wist their houre was spe[n]t; the[n] each to rest him hyes.
Did fiercely shake, and rowze, as comming late from rest.
In Princes court,---The rest she would haue said,
That my engreeued mind could find no rest,
Bene choisely picked out from all the rest,
But here a while ye may in safety rest,
Emongst the rest of those same ruefull sights,
To rest thy wearie person, in the shadow coole.
Ne man nor beast may rest, or take repast,
The rest had seuerall offices assind,
And all the rest, that noyous was, and nought,
That neuer idle was, ne once could rest a whit.
But Canute had his portion from the rest,
At last resolu'd likewise to proue the rest,
Yet liues his memorie, though carcas sleepe in rest.
As if the rest some wicked hand did rend,
Was as the rest, a grysie rablement,
That halfe the steele behind his back did rest;
This is the Port of rest from troublous toyle,
So made by art, to beautifie the rest,
Vnder that Porch a comely dame did rest,
The rest hid vnderneath, him more desirous made.
So held them vnder fast, the whiles the rest
But one aboue the rest in speciall,
That fairest vertue, farre aboue the rest;
Them to betake vnto their kindly rest;
Tho when the Britonesse saw all the rest
Could find no rest in such perplexed plight,
And if that any drop of slombring rest
Do lay away, and all wilde beastes do rest,
And that, which more then all the rest may sway,
So forth she rode without repose or rest,
But with sharpe speare the rest made dearly knowne.
But after all his warre, to rest his wearie knife.
She to her wagon clombe; clombe all the rest,
The rest of other fishes drawen weare,
Then all the rest into their coches clim,
But gentle Sleepe enuyde him any rest;
In stead of rest thou lendest rayling teares,
Desired rest, and men of happinesse depriue.
It lets not fall, it lets it not to rest:
But two of them the rest far ouerpast,
In easie couch his feeble limbes to rest,
That all the rest it seem'd they robbed bare
Where wearie of long trauell, downe to rest
The rest vpon her person gaue attendance great.
Great enimy to it, and to all the rest,
But nought that wanteth rest, can long aby.
To find some refuge there, and rest her weary syde.
That craue but rowme to rest, while tempest ouerblo'th.
And bidding her sit downe, to rest her faint
As glad of that small rest, as Bird of tempest gon.
Ne once to stay to rest, or breath at large,
And faire resemblance aboue all the rest,
From heauens blisse and euerlasting rest;
And neuer suffred her to be at rest:
Emongst the rest my lot (vnworthy) is to be one.
But to the rest, which in this Quest proceed
Vnto their rest, and all the keyes conuayd
Like as the rest, late entrance deare besought;
But like so as the rest he prayd for nought,
And eke that straunger knight emongst the rest;
From her left arme, to rest in glorious victorye.
Her crased health, her late recourse to rest,
Ere rest he found. Much there he suffered,
Toward the land; two riuers bound the rest.
So huge a mind could not in lesser rest,
Which after rest they seeking far abrode,
Them go to rest. So all vnto their bowres were brought.
The rest she fyr'd for sport, or for despight;
The rest he leaues in ground: so takes in hond
And did the rest with grieuous sighes suppresse,
And with pale eyes fast fixed on the rest,
And he emongst the rest crept forth in sory plight.
His rolling eyes did neuer rest in place,
Amongst the rest there was a iolly knight,
With speare in rest, and toward him did fare,
Till that the rest him seeing lie on ground,
Content to heare him speake, and glad to rest withall.
Vnto her rest in Plutoes griesly land,
He lightly lept out of his place of rest,
And sure had it not happily found rest
One in bright armes, with ready speare in rest,
To stirre vp strife, when most vs needeth rest,
Of his, on th'one; the rest on th'other side.
The rest them selues in troupes did else dispose,
But with no better fortune then the rest:
That all the rest it did amazed make,
Till trumpets sound did warne them all to rest;
But with no better fortune, then the rest afore.
Where I with sound of trompe will also rest a whyle.
And all the rest, which had the best afore,
The sight of whom once seene did all the rest dismay.
Whereat the rest gan greatly to enuie:
Whom when the rest did see her to refuse,
Amongst the rest with boastfull vaine pretense
Since with the rest she went not after Florimell.
Where they might hide their heads in quiet rest,
With huge great hammers, that did neuer rest
But in his armour layd him downe to rest:
To rest he layd him downe vpon the flore,
Her feeble ioynts layd eke a downe to rest;
The bellowes noyse disturb'd his quiet rest,
Long time resist, gaue place to kindly rest,
From foule mischance; ne did it euer rest,
Tho when they had long time there taken rest,
T'alight, and rest their wearie limbs awhile.
That did her passed paines in quiet rest assoyle.
I rest his wretched thrall, the sad AEmylia.
Amongst the rest a iewell rich he found,
In saluage chase, to rest as seem'd her meet.
And vnto rest themselues all onely lent,
Amongst the rest she chaunced there to see
Aboue the rest, that he sometimes may space
Amongst the rest, that Squire of low degree
To rest him selfe, and solace in soft pleasure
And by the rest did set in sumptuous chaire,
These paires of friends in peace and setled rest,
And rest themselues for to recouer spirits spent.
Diuided them, how euer loth to rest,
I neuer ioyed happinesse nor rest,
So gan the rest him likewise to require,
Since of my loue at length I rest assured,
That this same braue emprize for me did rest,
To sit and rest the walkers wearie shankes,
And to afflicted minds sweet rest and quiet sends.
Amongst the rest some one through loues constrayning,
And grauer countenance then all the rest;
Yet all the rest were eke her equall peares,
For stedfast still her eyes did fixed rest,
By virgins, and her sacrifices let to rest.
And Inachus renowmd aboue the rest;
Old Tethys, th'oldest two of all the rest,
For all the rest of those two parents came,
Sith no lesse famous then the rest they bee,
And there amongst the rest, the mother was
Amongst the rest, was faire Cymodoce,
By timely death shall winne her wished rest,
But most is Mars amisse of all the rest,
Most sacred vertue she of all the rest,
Would not so rest contented with his right,
Together ran with ready speares in rest.
So all the rest did others parts empaire.
So they disparted were, and all men went to rest.
Of all the rest, and then this warlike crew
When they are all restor'd, thou shalt rest in disgrace.
Her weary barke at last vppon mine Isle did rest.
Whether by rage of waues, that neuer rest,
I will not rest, till I her might doe trie,
But mongst the rest the fight did vntill euening last.
Warn'd man and beast in quiet rest be shrowded,
Where he him selfe did rest in safety,
Could take no rest, ne would receiue reliefe,
But Artegall him selfe to rest did dight,
Besides the rest dismayd, might not be nombred:
For such your kind regard, I can but rest your detter.
Yet in my truthes assurance I rest fixed fast.
I to your selfe should rest for euer bound,
The rest my selfe too readily can spell.
Forcing in vaine the rest to her to tell,
Who though desirous rather to rest mute,
Thus passing th'euening well, till time of rest,
And with sweete rest her heauy eyes did close,
That thorough euill rest of this last night,
In which stout Britomart her selfe did rest,
To serue her so, as she the rest had bound.
Ne day nor night did euer idly rest;
With speare in rest, and prickt with all his might:
He at him ran, with ready speare in rest:
For stint of strife, and stablishment of rest
So both for rest there hauing stayd not long,
Whose long rest rusted the bright steely brand;
Amongst the rest, which in that space befell,
Admyr'd of all the rest in presence there,
Vnto some place, where they mote rest and feede,
Then all the rest which in that Castle were,
Full loath to Belge, and to all the rest:
On which long way he rode, ne euer day did rest.
Then all the rest burst out to all outragiousnesse.
Into the rest, which round about you ring,
With that the rest, the which the Castle kept,
So they the euening past, till time of rest,
In couert shade him selfe did safely rest,
Till to some place of rest they mote attaine,
When day is spent, and rest vs needeth most,
To spare her Knight, and rest with reason pacifyde.
Compelled were themselues a while to rest,
They mote the abler be to passe vnto the rest.
His limbes would rest, ne lig in ease embost,
His steede now strong through rest so long a space,
Exceeding all the rest in powre and hight;
But faire Serene all night could take no rest,
Vpon the rest, that did aliue remaine;
The Prince himselfe there all that night did rest,
For all that night, the whyles the Prince did rest
He there in shade himselfe had layd to rest,
Yet would not let her lite, nor rest a little stead.
But Arthure with the rest, went onward still
With sorrow, she betooke her selfe to rest.
Each wisheth to him selfe, and to the rest enuyes.
For loue in soft delight thereon to rest;
Then to the rest his wrathfull hand he bends,
The rest that scape his sword and death eschew,
That day nor night he suffred him to rest,
Higher then all the rest, and round about
That all the rest like lesser lamps did dim:
Then all the rest about her rose likewise,
And rest himselfe, till supper time befell.
Which tosse the rest in daungerous disease?
My limbes in euery shade, to rest from toyle,
But fittest is, that all contented rest
To rest my barcke, which hath bene beaten late
That he of all the rest, which there did [d]well,
And set his rest amongst the rusticke sort,
As if this to adorne, she all the rest did pill.
And rest her selfe, as in a gladsome port,
The whilest the rest them round about did hemme,
That with her goodly presence all the rest much graced.
Seem'd all the rest in beauty to excell,
Doth she exceede the rest of all her race;
Amongst the rest, the which they then did pray,
And had the chiefe commaund of all the rest,
Ne day nor night he suffred her to rest,
But onely mongst the rest by her to sit,
Which with the rest they tooke not long agoe,
At last when all the rest them offred were,
The rest take if they would, he her to him would hold.
Should with the rest be sold before him theare,
To make the prises of the rest more deare.
Scarse yeelding her due food, or timely rest,
To greet him first, but askt were where the rest;
Whereat the knight amaz'd, yet did not rest,
That Pastorell yet liu'd, but all the rest
Whereof they both full glad and blyth did rest,
In dead of night, when all the theeues did rest
Where all the rest for him did readie stay,
There when they rested had a season dew,
Yet liuely vigour rested in his mind,
Ne rested they, till that to Faery lond
He rested him a while, and then the Mayd
Therewith he rested, and well pleased was.
Nathlesse she rested not so satisfide,
Ne rested till she cam without relent
Of his late fall, a while he rested still:
Yet rested not, but further gan inquire
But being well suffiz'd, them rested faine.
Ne rested he himselfe but natures dew,
In sommers shade himselfe here rested weary.
He breath'd his sword, and rested him till day:
And then againe returned to their restes:
Vp-rose Duessa from her resting place,
Vnto some resting place, which mote befall,
Of my fraile safetie, resting in the might
Let not his loue, let not his restlesse spright
Such restlesse passion did all night torment
Against that Castle restlesse siege did lay,
Like to a restlesse wheele, still running round,
But restlesse walketh all the world around,
Loue my lewd Pilot hath a restlesse mind
In restlesse anguish and vnquiet paine:
Who hauing left that restlesse house of Care,
Restlesse, recomfortlesse, with heart deepe grieued,
Not so the Princes, but with restlesse force,
Great perill of his life, and restlesse paines did take.
Reaping eternall glorie of his restlesse paines.
Dinting his brest, had bred his restlesse paine,
Through euery place, with restlesse paine and toile
Many Restoratiues of vertues rare,
And him restor'd to health, that would haue algates dyde.
So to his crowne she him restor'd againe,
Who shortly it to him restord againe,
He is againe vnto his rule restord,
Restord, and sory wounds right well recured,
Ere they to former rule restor'd shalbee,
As she were neuer hurt, was soone restor'd:
Was to that goodly fellowship restor'd,
Her wounds, that vnto strength restor'd her soone anew.
And him restor'd to healthfull state againe:
When they are all restor'd, thou shalt rest in disgrace.
That earst was dead, restor'd to life againe,
By which he had to her both life and loue restord.
Her tongue to her restord, then thus she sayd;
That may restore you to your wonted well?
Shall vs restore, none else from hence may vs vnbynd.
Himselfe wilth salues to health for to restore,
With equall eyes, their merites to restore,
So in short space they did to health restore
For vnto life the dead it could restore,
Whom his victorious hands did earst restore
Did life with vsury to him restore,
But when she saw no helpe might him restore,
Till he had made amends, and full restore
Sith I her dew reward cannot restore:
But that sweet Cordiall, which can restore
All wayes she sought, him to restore to plight,
Ne griefe might not his loue to him restore,
Restore vnto her health, and former state;
One drop of bloud to fall, but did restore
So did the warlike Britomart restore
And him restore to former grace againe.
Ye may redresse, and me restore to light.
And at his will may whom he list restore,
And vnto former liberty restore.
As if in stead thereof they Chaos would restore.
Was grieued to restore the pledge, he did possesse.
Chose Artegall to right her to restore;
He would to his owne part restore the same againe.
And all things to an equall to restore,
To Braggadochio did his shield restore:
Doth slay the Monster, and restore
His chearefull face, and light to men restore,
And to her kingdomes seat restore agayne;
If that no salues may vs to health restore?
Hauing subdew'd, yet did to life restore,)
But since things passed none may now restore,
He did them all to Coridon restore.
Thus hauing her restored trustily,
And him restoring vnto liuing light,
Which they had long vsurpt; and them restoring
He from such hardy boldnesse was restraind,
But when their bootlesse zeale she did restraine
But with outrageous strokes did him restraine,
From which sad ruth does seeme you to restraine,
First her restraine from her reprochfull blame,
And foes of life, she better can restraine;
Which he espying, cast her to restraine
And each the other from to rise restraine;
Her to restraine, and giue her good reliefe,
With gentle murmure, that his course they did restraine.
And with her prayers reasons to restraine
And loose affections streightly to restraine;
Ne Iudges powre, ne reasons rule mote them restraine.
Like to a stubborne steede whom strong hand would restraine.
But dread of shame my doubtfull lips doth still restraine.
The fell contagion may thereof restraine,
Nor bands of nature, that wilde beastes restraine,
His deare affect with silence did restraine,
And did from further violence restraine,
Your eies, your eares, your tongue, your talk restraine
Abstaine from pleasure, and restraine your will,
Whilst none was him to stop, nor none him to restraine.
Ne any is, that may him now restraine,
Where soone arriuing, they restrained were
Restraines those sterne behests, and cruell doomes of his.
Restraining stealth, and strong extortion;
Which he endured in his late restraint,
Till that the Palmer, by his graue restraint,
And to be free from hard restraint and gealous feares.
That weenes with watch and hard restraint to stay
Yet him perforce restraynd, and to him doubtfull sayd.
And their deuouring couetize restraynd,
Did him reproue, yet could him not restrayne,
But Hatred would my entrance haue restrayned,
And long restrayned of his ready course;
Would he restrayned be from his attendement.
Euen for stubborne pride, which her restrayned.
But hardly was restreined of that aged sire.
Yet rests not so, but other meanes doth make,
Ne euer rests he in tranquillity,
It neuer rests, till it haue wrought his finall bane.
The resty raynes, regarded now no more:
To weet, that I my trauell should resume,
My former shield I may resume againe:
Then that which he had to Sir Paridel resynd.
But th'other halfe did womans shape retaine,
Yet he his mothers lore did well retaine,
